The figure illustrates a Phillips curve.

The economy can return to the long-run equilibrium if it faces a boom and if wages are flexible by option (A) Wages will fall. When the economy experiences a boom, the price level will increase, and the long-run equilibrium will shift to the right. As a result, the short-run equilibrium will also shift to the right. In the short-run, the economy will experience an increase in supply, which will cause the price of labor to fall. This will lead to a decrease in wages, making labor more attractive to employers. As a result, the economy will return to the long-run equilibrium of the long-run Phillips curve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The short-run equilibrium real GDP is equal to the intersection of the SRAS curve and the vertical axis. The SRAS curve is given by the equation 1000 + 200e^(1000 - r) = 800e^(1000 - r), where r is the rate of interest. Solving for real GDP, we get real GDP = 1000 + 200e^(1000 - r) / e^r = 800e^r. Setting this equal to 800, we get e^r = 0.2, or r = 10%. Thus, the size of real GDP in the short-run equilibrium is 1000 + 200e^(1000 - 10%) = 500 billion. So the answer is (A).

This is consistent with the characteristics of a monopoly, as the monopolist can charge a higher price without increasing the output, which would lead to a decrease in marginal revenue. Additionally, the graph shows that the average cost is also constant, which further supports the existence of a monopoly in this market.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on macroeconomics for help. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is a measure of the average change over time of a fixed basket of goods and services consumed by households. It is calculated by dividing the change in the price of a basket of goods by the change in the volume of the basket. The basket of goods is usually a representative sample of all goods and services consumed by households. In this case, the basket of goods consists of 200 Apples and 290 Textbooks.
